title: 111_s3936
content: The "States as Energy Leaders for the Future Act" or "SELF Act" defines terms like "eligible entity" and "Secretary" for the Clean Energy Grant Program. The Department of Energy established a program to provide grants to eligible entities for clean energy and carbon reduction measures, including renewable electricity standards, climate action plans, use of alternative fuel vehicles, energy efficiency standards for public buildings, and participation in greenhouse gas reduction programs. The Department of Energy program provides grants for clean energy initiatives such as energy efficiency standards for public buildings, participation in greenhouse gas reduction programs, on-bill financing for energy improvements, state tax incentives for clean energy components, and innovative financing for clean energy technologies. To be eligible for a grant under this program, entities must implement clean energy technologies, innovative financing mechanisms, best management practices, grid technology improvements, and carbon efficiency standards. Eligible entities include states, local governments, or regional consortia. Entities eligible for grants must meet requirements set by the Secretary and submit an application. The Secretary will determine which entities receive awards. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities based on their applications and criteria set by regulation. Grant funds must be used for eligible purposes specified by the Secretary. The Secretary will issue regulations establishing criteria for grants, specifying eligible measures, application criteria, and a point system for reviewing grant applications. The Secretary will develop regulations for grants, including specifying eligible measures, application criteria, and a point system for reviewing applications, taking into account regional disparities and clean energy potential. The Secretary will publish an explanation in the Federal Register on how grants awarded under the Act will be objectively evaluated based on specified criteria and regulations. Authorization of $5 billion for fiscal year 2011 to carry out the Act, with funds remaining available until expended. Cost offset for clean energy grant program and deficit reduction by denying deduction for major integrated oil companies for income from domestic production of oil, gas, or primary products. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes a provision for major integrated oil companies to qualify for oil-related production activities. This is a conforming amendment to deny deductions for income from domestic oil, gas, or primary products. The amendment allows major integrated oil companies to qualify for oil-related production activities. This amendment denies deductions for income from domestic oil, gas, or primary products. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010.
